newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee ends mixed before Christmas break.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee ends mixed before Christmas break.

text.p: London coffee futures stood mixed within tight ranges on Tuesday midsession as the market shut for Christmas holidays and will not re-open until December 27.
Traders said quiet morning exchanges involved mainly locals trading between themselves.
"I can't put a finger on anything, it's so quiet," commented one.

The benchmark March contract $3 to $1,235 a tonne, just above its session low of $1,233, staying clear of nearby support at $1,225. The following two following positions, May and July, were firmer. Turnover reached a relatively mild 1,917 lots.
The London International Financial Futures Exchange (LIFFE) where robusta coffee futures trade will be closed from Tuesday midsession for Christmas. It will re-open on Friday.
Traders said Tuesday's short session was also pressured by the new U.S. certified coffee stocks data which nearly tripled in the week ending December 20 to 34,315 60-kg bags.
But reaction was somewhat muted with most players away.
Technically, robusta is seen likely to drift in the short-term to gather momentum to tackle upside barriers but the long-term outlook is bearish.
March is initially capped by its 10-day moving average of $1,259, but a crucial test of resistance comes in at $1,300. Downside support is pegged at $1,225 and $1,205.
